item.title: Ukraine and Europe Chafe at Being Excluded From U.S.-Russian Peace Plan
item.description: Some in Kyiv expressed confusion over the Trump administration’s multiple diplomatic tracks as Washington tries to revive negotiations.

item.title: Trump to Send U.S. Official to G20 in South Africa After All
item.description: The decision to have an acting ambassador attend the Group of 20 in South Africa came after the president said the United States would boycott.

item.title: Laurence des Cars, Louvre’s President, Defends Her Tenure
item.description: In one of her very few interviews since the museum heist, Laurence des Cars said the plan would increase much-needed security, but critics say it is too focused on new construction.

item.title: Iran Withdraws From Deal for International Nuclear Inspections
item.description: Iran’s foreign minister said his country would halt plans for a reinstatement of nuclear inspections at a time of heightened concern over Iran’s enriched uranium.

item.title: The Climate Is Changing, Cows Are Stressed and Italy’s Cheesemakers Are Worried
item.description: Extreme heat causes cows to produce less milk. This poses problems in cheese-obsessed Italy, especially as it tries to meet growing demand for favorites like burrata.

item.title: The Hunt Is On for Bears in Japan After Deadly Attacks
item.description: Residents in the northern region of Akita are living in fear after dozens of assaults on humans. Riot police and the army have been sent to help.

item.title: Trump Meeting With Saudi Prince Showcased Prince’s Makeover, and America’s
item.description: Mohammed bin Salman was briefly a global pariah after the killing of a Saudi dissident. But he has rebuilt his image as a deal-maker and influential investor.

item.title: Israeli Strikes Kill at Least 25 in Gaza Amid Cease-Fire, Officials Say
item.description: Israel’s military said it had launched attacks across Gaza after Palestinian militants shot at its troops. The six-week-old cease-fire has been pierced periodically by bursts of violence.

item.title: Ferry Crashed After Operator Was Distracted by His Phone, Officials Say
item.description: The operator and two other officers were charged with gross negligence after the ferry ran aground in South Korea on Wednesday carrying 267 people.

item.title: Mount Semeru Erupts and Rains Ash on Villages
item.description: Mount Semeru on the island of Java is one of Indonesia’s most active volcanoes. Its latest eruption forced hundreds to flee their homes.

item.title: Move Over, Netflix: Ukraine’s Corruption Investigators Bring the Drama
item.description: The country’s anti-graft agencies have taken a cinematic approach to revealing a scandal that has touched President Volodymyr Zelensky’s inner circle.

item.title: Ex-Mayor Is Sentenced to Life for Human Trafficking Tied to Scam Centers
item.description: A court in the Philippines convicted Alice Guo for trafficking people to a compound that officials have linked to online scams and organized crime.

item.title: As the World Pursues Clean Power, Millions Still Have No Power at All
item.description: Just outside Belém, the Amazonian city where the world is meeting to discuss climate change, electricity is a very recent arrival.

item.title: Ambassador Huckabee Held Meeting With Jonathan Pollard, Ex-Spy, at U.S. Embassy in Israel
item.description: Jonathan J. Pollard, who was convicted of espionage, said in an interview that the meeting, which was highly unusual for a U.S. diplomat to attend, had been friendly.

item.title: Is Scalp Care the New Big Beauty Trend?
item.description: Consumers are increasingly fixating on their scalps, turning to head spas, pricey treatments and products to combat thin hair and irritation.

item.title: She Studied How to Protect Children From Pollution and Heat
item.description: “There was no warning, no conversation,” said Jane Clougherty, an environmental health scientist, who had a federal grant canceled earlier this year.

item.title: Family Who Died While Visiting Istanbul May Have Been Poisoned, Authorities Say
item.description: Investigators are examining whether the family of four from Germany, including two children, died from exposure to a toxic chemical found in their hotel room.

item.title: How Japan Is Tackling Its Bear Problem
item.description: Bear attacks are at record levels in Japan, with more than a dozen people killed this year. Javier C. Hernández, our Tokyo bureau chief, looks at the causes and how Japan is responding.

item.title: Franco Died 50 Years Ago, but He’s Still Winning New Fans in Spain
item.description: Young Spaniards are increasingly drawn to the dictator Francisco Franco. So the government is designing apps, games and T-shirts to promote democracy.

item.title: Northern Ireland Must Change How Its Schools Teach Religion, Court Says
item.description: The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom said Northern Ireland’s public schools must include the study of faiths other than Christianity.

item.title: Mexico Is Now the United States’ Top Buyer
item.description: For first time in at least 30 years, the United States has exported more to Mexico than Canada, U.S. government data show, in a sign of how much North American trade has consolidated.

item.title: They Loved Their Family Land in South Carolina. But Who Actually Owned It?
item.description: Conservation can be tough when a property is passed down informally over generations. A growing effort is helping families sort it all out.

item.title: Alberta Invokes Last-Resort Constitutional Clause to Shield Trans Laws From Challenges
item.description: The western province’s conservative government has invoked a rarely used clause in Canada’s Constitution to shield its bills limiting transgender rights from legal challenges.

item.title: Police Found $1 Million in a Tub Under a Garage. The Government Gets to Keep It.
item.description: A court ruled that the hidden cash, which the police found while searching for an illegal gun in Ontario, did not lawfully belong to the man living on the property.

item.title: F.B.I. Hunt Intensifies for Ryan Wedding, Snowboarder Accused of Being a Drug Kingpin
item.description: Ryan Wedding, a former Olympic athlete said to be a major cocaine trafficker, is accused of ordering the murder of a witness who was set to testify against him.

item.title: U.S.-Russian Peace Plan Would Force Ukraine to Cede Land and Cut Army
item.description: The 28-point proposal, which comes as the Trump administration tries to restart settlement talks, includes demands long rejected by Kyiv as nonstarters.

item.title: Henry Todd, LSD Kingpin Turned Everest Guide, Dies at 80
item.description: He helped make and distribute millions of LSD tablets in the 1970s. After seven years in prison, he ran mountain climbing expeditions in the Himalayas.

item.title: What Happened to Europe’s Terrorism Problem?
item.description: Not that long ago, big attacks were a daily concern. We look at why it feels different now.

item.title: Old Divides of East and West Haunt Germany’s Newest Arrivals
item.description: Refugees who poured into the country a decade ago fared better when they landed in the more prosperous West, an enduring legacy of reunification.

item.title: Two Miss Universe Judges Resign Before Finale, Deepening a Crisis
item.description: One accused the competition of being rigged. It is the second scandal to roil the pageant after an organizer berated a contestant in public.

item.title: Zelensky Under Siege as Corruption Case Shatters Ukraine’s Wartime Unity
item.description: An anti-Zelensky political coalition is coalescing as the president’s allies are accused of enriching themselves while the country’s soldiers die on the battlefield.

item.title: Russian Missile Kills at Least 25 in Ukrainian Apartment Building
item.description: The attack was part of a wave of strikes across the country as President Volodymyr Zelensky seeks to revive stalled peace talks.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Sent Trade Plummeting in August
item.description: The steep tariffs President Trump issued in August led to a contraction in imports and the trade deficit, newly released data shows.

item.title: Iran Releases Tanker It Seized From the Strait of Hormuz
item.description: The ship had lost contact with its managers while traveling near Iran on its way to Singapore last week. All 21 members of the crew are safe.

item.title: Trump Team Calls Maduro a ‘Cartel’ Boss. That Word Doesn’t Mean What You Think.
item.description: Venezuelans coined a figure of speech for the phenomenon of generals corrupted by drug money: “Cartel de los Soles.” Then the United States started talking about it as a literal organization.

item.title: Trump Said to Authorize C.I.A. Plans for Covert Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has signed off on possible operations inside Venezuela but has also reopened back-channel communications with the government of President Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Trump Lauds M.B.S. During White House Visit and Dismisses Khashoggi’s Killing
item.description: President Trump rejected a U.S. intelligence report finding that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman had ordered the murder of a journalist.

item.title: What to Know About the Corruption Scandal Roiling Ukraine
item.description: An investigation into the state-owned nuclear power company has reached members of President Volodymyr Zelensky’s inner circle.

item.title: Investigating a Recycling Disaster
item.description: We went to Nigeria, where recycling plants are extracting lead for use in American and European car batteries — at a terrible human cost.

item.title: Trump Family’s Business Ties to Saudi Arabia Raise Ethics Worries
item.description: President Trump will host Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler, who oversees a major construction project that is in talks with the Trump family business.

item.title: Australian Man Convicted of Murderer Sues to Challenge Vegemite Ban Behind Bars
item.description: A man facing life behind bars is challenging the state of Victoria’s prison ban on the salty condiment beloved by many Australians. The case drew condemnation from a minister for corrections.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: The president is offering the crown prince fighter jets, a nuclear agreement and other deals as part of his efforts to collect investment and push forward on Middle East peace.

item.title: Israeli Airstrike on Refugee Camp in Lebanon Kills at Least 13, Officials Say
item.description: It was one of the deadliest Israeli strikes on Lebanon since a cease-fire with Hezbollah went into effect about a year ago.

item.title: Cloudflare Outage Disrupts X, ChatGPT and Other Parts of the Internet
item.description: Services from Cloudflare, a software company, underpin thousands of websites, including X, Spotify and OpenAI. The company said a crash in a software system was to blame.

item.title: Frustrated With Your Home Insurer? Tell Us About It.
item.description: Help us track trends in the home insurance market by filling out this survey.

item.title: ‘Things Happen’: Trump Brushes Off the Murder of Khashoggi
item.description: A reporter asked Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman about the murder of the Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi. President Trump interjected.

item.title: The Saudi crown prince receives an especially warm welcome at the White House.
U.S. Military Threat Puts Spotlight on Venezuela’s Allies
item.description: American adversaries are unlikely to help President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela fend off a concerted attack. But they have made toppling him harder.

item.title: Environmentalists Sue to Stop Oil Lease Sales in the Gulf of Mexico
item.description: A Trump administration proposal to allow more exploration for oil and gas violates environmental laws, the groups said.

item.title: Khashoggi’s widow wants the U.S. to pressure Saudi Arabia to return his remains.
item.description: James Khashoggi, U.

item.title: Chinese Spies Are Using LinkedIn to Target U.K. Lawmakers, MI5 Warns
item.description: Britain’s domestic intelligence agency said China was using headhunters to gather intelligence from lawmakers and parliamentary staff members.

item.title: Poland Blames Russian-Backed Ukrainians for Railway Sabotage
item.description: Two devices on a main supply line to Ukraine were intended to derail passing trains but failed, the prime minister said, and the two suspects fled the country.

item.title: For the Saudi crown prince, international criticism over the killing of Jamal Khashoggi has faded.
Trump wants a Saudi-Israel deal, but that’s not likely soon.
Zelensky Will Try to Revive Peace Talks With Russia During Turkey Visit
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says he has new proposals to kick-start negotiations with Russia that have been stalled for months.

item.title: UN Support Propels Trump Gaza Plan, but Road Ahead Is Still Rough
item.description: The Security Council’s backing offered a scaffolding of international legitimacy that will be needed to persuade countries to help see the plans through.

item.title: Ecuador Votes ‘No’ to Hosting U.S. Military Base
item.description: A vote on Sunday rejected the expansion of a foreign military presence. It came as the U.S. military’s campaign in waters near Latin America has been roiling the region.

item.title: Jeju Air Crash Investigators to Hold Public Hearing as They Face Criticism
item.description: With the cause of the disaster in South Korea still unclear after nearly a year, victims’ families have questioned the credibility and impartiality of the inquiry board.

item.title: Greenpeace Faces an Unusual New Legal Attack From a Pipeline Giant
item.description: The company that won a huge verdict against Greenpeace earlier this year has asked a North Dakota court to block a countersuit in the Netherlands.
